name: Radioship
description: Radioship is an open-source language model engine designed to facilitate speech-to-text conversion for under-explored languages. It utilizes the language corpora from Mozilla Common Voice, an open-ai project that supports linguistic diversity.

sdgs.relevance:
SDG4 and SDG10: Radioship contributes to SDG4 by enhancing the accessibility of audio content in lesser-known languages through transcription, making it easier for people to understand and learn from diverse linguistic resources. Additionally, our speech-to-text technology supports SDG10 by breaking barriers and ensuring inclusivity. By making vast audio archives, such as radio broadcasts, searchable, we unveil valuable hidden content, promoting cultural understanding and diversity.

SDG17: Radioship aims to foster global collaborations among community radios. Our open-source speech-to-text tool facilitates audio archive searches, encouraging partnerships and knowledge sharing. By enabling community radios worldwide to use our technology, we promote SDG17's goal of strengthening partnerships for sustainable development.

clearOwnership.clearOwnershipURL:
There is a partnership agreement between the contributors at the moment to deliver this solution within one year fulfilling the donor's requirement. We have no other legal evidence or formal agreement about the actual ownership yet. We can consider the founder individuals (Zoltán Varjú, Gergely Gazda, József Venczeli, Szabolcs Kincse, Edit Köles) and the participating organizational entities (Civil Radio, Tilos Radio, Nyest.hu) as owners.

Some public evidences:
Contributors and committers of the GitHub organization:
https://github.com/orgs/Koffair/people

Partners are listed on the website with their logos on the top, and individuals mentioned at the bottom in the "Who We Are" section.
https://www.radioship.org/

documentation:
Our github repository is https://github.com/Koffair. 

The steps of creating a language model for your own are described in a Python notebook format: https://github.com/Koffair/colab_pipelines/tree/main/notebooks

The usage of our speech-to-text CLI is documented in the readme file: https://github.com/Koffair/radioship_transcriber

You can access the existing (Hungarian) model on huggingface.co:
https://huggingface.co/radioship/wav2vec2-large-xlsr-53-hu

bestPractices:
During the development we followed the agile principles.
We have been using epics

user stories bi-weekly plannings and retrospectives to break down our task and reflect and improve our processes.
We use standard git flow with pull request and pair-reviews.
